author: By Mara Gay and David Firestone
title: Things Have Gotten Pretty Weird With New York’s Mayor
description: A conversation about Mayor Adams’s weak leadership at a time when New York City is at an inflection point.
content: David Firestone: Hi, Mara, and welcome to a year that’s going to be full of news about Mayor Eric Adams and the long-term health of New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Parenting: A ‘Wonderful and Challenging Adventure’
description: Readers discuss the negativity that pervades discussions about parenthood. Also: Aligning election calendars; natural gas exports; semicolons.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Joan Acocella, Dance Critic for The New Yorker, Dies at 78
description: She wrote about the leading figures in ballet and modern dance for more than 40 years. One of her books was about the brash choreographer Mark Morris.
content: Joan Acocella, a cultural critic whose erudite, elegant essays about dance and literature appeared in The New Yorker and The New York Review of Books over four decades, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing Again Under Scrutiny After Latest 737 Max Problem
description: A sudden hole appearing in the side of an Alaska Airlines plane midflight follows years of problems with the manufacturer’s aircraft.
content: A harrowing flight over the weekend is again forcing Boeing to confront concerns over its planes, particularly the 737 Max, already one of the most scrutinized jets in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Paul Giamatti Has Done the Reading
description: For his role in “The Holdovers,” set at a prep school not unlike the one he attended, the hyper-literate actor mined his own dormant memories.
content: Paul Giamatti would just like to put it out there that maybe he doesn’t always have to play such a motormouth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg and Santul Nerkar
title: American Unions Long Backed Israel. Now, Some Are Protesting It.
description: The shift reflects a broader generational change, and has exposed philosophical rifts in the labor movement about what the purpose of a union ought to be.
content: “Why are we here?” said Brandon Mancilla, a leader with the United Automobile Workers. Mr. Mancilla faced a crowd of hundreds of union members gathered on the steps of the New York Public Library’s Fifth Avenue branch, huddling against the cold as they rallied for a cease-fire in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaan Sachdev
title: Baudelaire Would Be Run Over in New York City Today
description: A city that no longer accommodates wandering no longer accommodates wondering. A flâneur without freedom falls into a zombified routine.
content: In his 1863 essay “The Painter of Modern Life,” Charles Baudelaire described the passionate city dweller as “a kaleidoscope gifted with consciousness.” In the French poet’s eyes, the city dweller had a unique opportunity to absorb and mirror the poetry of freely moving multitudes. For the committed flâneur, Baudelaire wrote, “the crowd is his element, as the air is that of birds and water of fishes.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 7, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 7, 2024.
content: An article last Sunday about “Car­men” at the Metropolitan Opera misstated the performance history of the Russian mezzo-­soprano Aigul Akhmetshina. She has performed at the Met before; “Carmen” is not her Met debut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Blessing of Same-Sex Couples Rankles Africa’s Catholics
description: It is out of step with the continent’s values, many bishops say, and threatens to derail expansion in the church’s fastest growing region in the world.
content: The Vatican’s recent declaration allowing the blessing of same-sex couples caused a stir around the globe, but perhaps most of all in Africa, a rising center of the Roman Catholic Church’s future. In one statement after the next, bishops in several countries spoke of the fear and confusion the declaration has caused among their flocks, and said it was out of step with the continent’s culture and values.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
title: From Lebanon to the Red Sea, a Broader Conflict With Iran Looms
description: With its proxies attacking from many vantage points and its nuclear program suddenly revived, Iran is posing a new challenge to the West — this time with Russia and China on its side.
content: President Biden and his top national security aides believed last summer that the chances of conflict with Iran and its proxies were well contained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Mário Zagallo, Longtime Fixture of Brazilian Soccer, Dies at 92
description: The first person to win the World Cup as a player and a coach, he was a link to decades of Brazil’s success and failure on the sport’s biggest stage.
content: Mário Zagallo, who as both a player and coach helped lead Brazil to four World Cup soccer championships, becoming a national hero and one of only three people to lift the tournament’s trophy in both roles, died on Friday in Rio de Janeiro. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: She Helped the Lillys Blossom. Now She’ll Champion Her Own Work.
description: After years of fighting to win parity and recognition for women in theater, Julia Jordan said: “Everybody gets produced now. There’s much more competition. In a good way.”
content: Ask the playwright Julia Jordan what the need was for the Lilly Awards, which she co-founded in 2010 to honor women in theater, and the answer is a mix of anecdote and statistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Erin Schaff
title: Marijuana Buyers From Texas Fuel a ‘Little Amsterdam’ in New Mexico
description: Sunland Park, along the Rio Grande, has joined the ranks of U.S. cities transformed by state cannabis laws. But the good times may not last forever.
content: In a desert valley along the Rio Grande in New Mexico, the city of Sunland Park has generally offered few amenities for its roughly 17,000 residents. No large grocery store. Few shops. Little to offer those uninterested in the racetrack casino or a hike to the gigantic cross of Cristo Del Rey that looms from a nearby mountaintop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Beller
title: Manet and Degas and Robert and Me
description: A monumental art exhibit at the Met explored the kind of rivalry that can complicate, and fortify, a friendship. I recognized it all too well.
content: Near the end of the “Manet/Degas” exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, there is a small drawing by Edgar Degas of a bearish man with a beard. At first glance, you might think the man in the drawing is Edouard Manet, but in fact he’s an author and critic named Edmond Duranty. Nine years before this drawing was created, Duranty had written something critical of Manet, in response to which Manet, encountering Duranty in a cafe, slapped him. Duranty demanded that Manet apologize. Manet refused. Durante challenged Manet to a duel. The duel, by sword, took place three days later. Manet was unscathed; I guess you could say he won. Duranty, the man in the Degas drawing, “received a wound in his upper chest,” as the museum text accompanying the drawing states matter-of-factly. I stared incredulously at the text’s last line: “Surprisingly, the two men remained friends after the incident.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Vulcan Rocket Prepares for First Launch of Moon Lander Mission
description: Here’s what you need to know about United Launch Alliance and the robotic lunar spacecraft it is sending to orbit.
content: A brand-new American rocket is on a launchpad at Cape Canaveral, Fla., and for the first time in more than 50 years, an American spacecraft will be headed toward the surface of the moon. The rocket is called Vulcan, and it was built by the company United Launch Alliance. Here’s what you need to know about its first flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Japanese Company’s Bid for U.S. Steel Tests Biden’s Industrial Policy
description: The president is under pressure from Democrats and Republicans to block the sale to Japan’s Nippon Steel, which could upset a key foreign ally.
content: U.S. Steel is an iconic example of the lost manufacturing muscle that President Biden says his economic policies will bring back to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: I Finally Figured Out Who ChatGPT Reminds Me Of
description: Generative A.I. is often described as being in its infancy. The truth is a little more of a handful.
content: As the mother of an 8-year-old, and as someone who’s spent the past year experimenting with generative A.I., I’ve thought a lot about the connection between interacting with one and with the other. I’m not alone in this. A paper published in August in the journal Nature Human Behaviour explained how, during its early stages, an artificial intelligence model will try lots of things randomly, narrowing its focus and getting more conservative in its choices as it gets more sophisticated. Kind of like what a child does. “A.I. programs do best if they start out like weird kids,” writes Alison Gopnik, a developmental psychologist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Subway Service Is Fully Restored After Derailment in Manhattan
description: The 1, 2 and 3 lines were back in service after tracks were repaired, and an investigation was continuing into the cause of a collision last week.
content: Subway service on the 1, 2 and 3 train lines in Manhattan was fully restored on Sunday, more than 60 hours after a collision between two trains left 26 people injured, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said in a social media post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: A Terrible Phone Call and What Came Next
description: A cancer diagnosis, a Swedish proverb and the blessing of human connection
content: Early on the morning of Friday, Nov. 10, my phone rang with terrible news: My wife, Nancy, has a highly aggressive form of breast cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: Golden Globes Winners 2024: The Complete List
description: The winning films, TV shows, actors and production teams at the 2024 Golden Globe Awards.
content: Tuning into the Golden Globes this year meant more than catching a glimpse of the stars or getting an idea of what the Oscars might have in store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: The Mystery of the Coin That Shouldn’t Exist
description: Scientists recently analyzed a Peruvian 10-cent piece with an unexplained origin.
content: A decade ago, a funny money mystery fell into the hands of scientists and students at the Pontifical Catholic University of Peru in Lima.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan McCrea
title: A Day in the Kitchen at The New York Times Cooking Studio
description: The sunlit space buzzes with activity, as photographers and photo editors, food stylists and their assistants prep and cook, frame and reframe, in pursuit of the most mouthwatering shot.
content: Like so many things in the world of food, it starts, often, with a smell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: Bangladesh’s Troubled Election
description: Plus why the first galaxies were banana-shaped.
content: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh was nearly guaranteed a fourth consecutive term in office as voting ended in a low-turnout election yesterday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Writing Checks Can Be Risky. Here’s How To Protect Yourself.
description: Should you keep a separate checking account for writing checks? Is there a specific pen you should use? We answer some reader questions.
content: Typewriters vanished, and then cassette tapes and encyclopedias did, too. But paper checks are one piece of our analog past that persists.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Joked That Maybe We Could See Each Other Out Our Windows’
description: College roommates get a surprise, dropped mango slices and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Amanda Holpuch
title: Winter Storm Hits the Northeast, Bringing a Foot of Snow to Some Areas
description: Forecasters warned of low visibility and dangerous driving conditions during the heaviest snowfall, which could reach one to two inches per hour.
content: The first major storm of the winter season dropped more than a foot of snow in parts of the Northeast on Saturday, creating treacherous travel conditions in some areas while also bringing an end to a mostly snowless winter so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: The Secret Weapon of Celebrity Stylists? Comfortable Shoes.
description: What do Queen Camilla, Julia Roberts and Gayle King have in common? Sole Bliss. The brand has become a go to for women who don’t want to suffer foot pain.
content: Helen Mirren declared herself to be “in love with them,” and Gabrielle Union said that “they might be the most comfortable shoes I have ever worn in my life.” Julia Roberts, Viola Davis and Drew Barrymore have worn them to Hollywood premieres. Queen Camilla owns 13 pairs and wears them at almost all of her public engagements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Klee Benally, Navajo Activist and Artist, Dies at 48
description: He helped found a punk-rock band when he was 14. That led to a long career as an advocate for Native American and environmental causes.
content: Klee Benally, a dynamic Navajo activist, artist and punk-rock musician who championed Native American and environmental causes, died on Dec. 30 in Phoenix. He was 48.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: War Brings Tensions, and Assault Rifles, Into an Israeli College
description: At the University of Haifa, more than 40 percent of students are Arab, some with family in Gaza, and many others have now been called up as soldiers.
content: In a classroom at the University of Haifa in late December, Yitzhak Cohen, a fourth-year law student, began the shoulder-shrugging, arm-contorting choreography familiar to any student trying to remove a backpack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Neil Vigdor
title: Michigan Republicans Hold Disputed Vote to Remove Party Leader
description: The effort to oust the state’s controversial G.O.P. chair after infighting and financial troubles faces challenges from her allies and is likely headed to the courts.
content: Simmering tensions within the Michigan Republican Party boiled over on Saturday, with some party officials voting to remove their embattled chairwoman, Kristina Karamo, in a contentious proceeding that she and other state Republicans argued was illegitimate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Color Purple’ Struggles at Box Office After Big Christmas Opening
description: The musical adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel seemed an instant hit, but it sold less than $5 million in tickets in its second weekend.
content: “The Color Purple,” a new musical take on Alice Walker’s landmark novel, seemed to arrive as an instant hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: With Shutdown Looming, House and Senate Leaders Agree on Spending Levels
description: Despite the deal, time is short to assemble and pass legislation putting the agreement in force before a Jan. 19 deadline.
content: Senate and House leaders announced on Sunday that they had struck an overarching agreement on 2024 government funding, but it was not clear whether they would be able to cement the deal and pass it into law in time to avert a partial government shutdown in less than two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Norby Walters, 91, Dies; Music and Sports Agent Who Ran Afoul of the Law
description: He ran a highly successful booking agency, but his secret contacts with college athletes led to convictions (later reversed) for racketeering and fraud.
content: Norby Walters, a booking agent for some of the country’s top disco, R&B, funk and hip-hop artists whose aggressive leap in the 1980s into signing college athletes to secret contracts before they turned pro led to legal problems, died on Dec. 10 in Burbank, Calif. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Dignified burials have become another casualty in Gaza.
description: For four days, Kareem Sabawi’s body lay wrapped in a blanket in a cold, empty apartment as his family sheltered nearby. He was killed during intense Israeli bombardment near his family home, his father and mother said, and in the days that followed, it was too dangerous to step outside and lay their 10-year-old child to rest.
content: For four days, Kareem Sabawi’s body lay wrapped in a blanket in a cold, empty apartment as his family sheltered nearby. He was killed during intense Israeli bombardment near his family home, his father and mother said, and in the days that followed, it was too dangerous to step outside and lay their 10-year-old child to rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Ameera Harouda
title: Two More Journalists Killed in Gaza, Including Son of Al Jazeera Reporter
description: Hamza al-Dahdouh, the son of Al Jazeera’s Gaza bureau chief, and a second reporter were killed in what officials in the territory said was an Israeli airstrike. Two others were wounded.
content: Wael al-Dahdouh, a well-known Palestinian correspondent for Al Jazeera TV who has spent his career covering Gaza, had already lost his wife, a son, a daughter and an infant grandson in an Israeli airstrike in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Swelled Heads
description: Nate Cardin ropes us in.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker and Niraj Chokshi
title: F.A.A. Orders Airlines to Ground Some Boeing 737 Max 9 Jets After Midair Emergency
description: An Alaska Airlines plane made an emergency landing at the Portland, Ore., airport on Friday after a hole opened up in the plane while it was in flight.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration on Saturday ordered U.S. airlines to stop using some Boeing 737 Max 9 planes until they were inspected, after one of those planes lost a piece of its body in midair, terrifying passengers until the plane landed safely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
title: Bangladesh Votes in Election Marred by Crackdown and Boycotts
description: With the opposition in jail or off the ballots, the prime minister for the past 15 years is expected to maintain her grip on power in what appeared to be a low-turnout vote.
content: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh was nearly guaranteed a fourth consecutive term in office as voting ended on Sunday in a low-turnout election that has been marred by a widespread crackdown on the opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Miharu Nishiyama
title: Woman Rescued From Rubble in Japan Five Days After Deadly Quake
description: The survivor, who was in her 90s, was dug out from under a collapsed house, injured but responsive.
content: The police and other rescue workers pulled a woman in her 90s out from under a collapsed house on Saturday in western Japan, five days after a powerful earthquake struck the region, killing more than 126 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken, in Jordan and Qatar, continues his Mideast tour in hopes of reducing tensions.
description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met separately in Amman with King Abdullah II and Ayman Safadi, Jordan’s foreign minister.
content: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, held meetings on Sunday with leaders in Jordan and Qatar as part of a weeklong eastern Mediterranean and Middle East tour aimed at reducing the risk that the war in Gaza could spread in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Takes Aim at Haley as Primary Enters Final Phase in Iowa
description: Nearly a week before the state’s caucuses, a frenzy of campaigning belies a seemingly static G.O.P. race, with former President Donald J. Trump the prohibitive front-runner.
content: Donald J. Trump’s escalating attacks on Nikki Haley both on the airwaves and at his rallies — criticisms she likened Saturday to “a temper tantrum” — captured the turbulent dynamics in the final week before the first votes of the 2024 Republican presidential primary are cast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Spatchcocked Roast Chicken is a Better Roast Chicken
description: A de-backboned, flattened bird roasts more quickly and evenly, with juicy meat under crisp, burnished skin. Sohla El-Waylly shows us how.
content: Good morning. I’m just spitballing here, but I bet the use of the word “spatchcocking” — which describes the business of cutting the backbone out of a bird and flattening the remaining body into a pan so that it roasts more quickly and evenly — peaks around Thanksgiving, at least in America. A spatchcocked turkey is a marvelous thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Pressure Builds on Pentagon to Explain Timeline of Austin’s Hospitalization
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin has yet to disclose why he has been at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center for the past week.
content: The Pentagon came under increased pressure Sunday to explain why senior Biden administration officials, congressional representatives and the president himself were not notified of the hospitalization of Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III until days later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Who Was the Mysterious Woman Buried Alone at the Pet Cemetery?
description: At Hartsdale Pet Cemetery, Ed Martin III had become accustomed to unusual requests. Then came Patricia Chaarte.
content: Ed Martin III was 14 years old when he began working at his father’s pet cemetery, and in the decades since he has tended to the graves of innumerable dogs, many cats, flocks of birds, a few monkeys, a lion cub, a Bengal tiger and countless other creatures from every corner of the animal kingdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin McCann
title: London Tube Strike Is Called Off
description: London’s mayor announced late Sunday afternoon that a strike that would have crippled the city’s transit system this week had been suspended.
content: The mayor of London on Sunday announced that a planned strike that would have ground the city’s underground Tube system to a halt this week had been suspended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Edward Wong and Thomas Fuller
title: As West Bank Violence Rises, Israel Vows to Pursue Military Goals in Gaza
description: Diplomats toured the Mideast Sunday on a mission to stop the war from widening, but tensions in the Gaza Strip spread across the region.
content: JERUSALEM — As the war in the Gaza Strip ended its third month on Sunday , with top diplomats touring the region to try to stop the conflict from spreading, Israel said it had broken up Hamas’s command structure in northern Gaza and signaled that it would not change its objective of dismantling the group’s capabilities across the ravaged territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Yasmin Marikar
title: How a Millennial Estée Lauder Built a Widely Popular Beauty Brand
description: Karissa Bodnar played on her customers’ desire to belong to something bigger than … well, beauty.
content: On a recent Monday, Karissa Bodnar, the 34-year-old founder and chief executive of Thrive, a cosmetics company, arrived at a launch party for her latest product line. The setting: a fluorescent-lit, fifth-floor office in midtown Manhattan. The bells and whistles: cheese, crudités, basic beer and wine. The entertainment: a Bluetooth speaker playing early aughts hip-hop (Flo Rida, Lil Jon).
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 8, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 8, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo and Corey Schreppel
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Ghosts on the Glacier’
description: Decades after the unexplained deaths of two American climbers in Argentina, a camera belonging to one of them was found in the snow.
content: Fifty years ago, eight Americans set off for South America to climb Aconcagua, one of the world’s mightiest mountains. Things quickly went wrong. Two climbers died. Their bodies were left behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Why New York Has Faltered in Making Childbirth Safer for Black Mothers
description: Proposals to reverse stark racial disparities in who dies during childbirth face deep-rooted obstacles, including hospital quality and the pandemic’s uneven aftereffects.
content: Late last year, a 30-year-old woman, Christine Fields, died after giving birth at a public hospital in Brooklyn. Within a few weeks, inspectors from the New York State Department of Health arrived and began pulling medical files and interviewing doctors and nurses, the agency said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: What Will Happen to Gaza’s People?
description: Officials are increasingly suggesting that Palestinians should leave the region. The government denies that’s its policy.
content: Conventional wisdom has generally held that Israel’s government lacks a strategy for the Gaza Strip beyond toppling Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora
title: ‘Two Men Down’: For Ukrainian Medics, It Was Time to Move
description: They are the first line of treatment for soldiers wounded on the battlefield, racing against time to try to save lives.
content: To save lives, Ukrainian combat medics must stay alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Taylor Swift Shows Up but Leaves Empty-Handed.
description: Swift has five nominations but no wins after “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour” lost to “Barbie” in the new blockbuster film category.
content: Taylor Swift is back in her Golden Globes era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: The Road to the Oscars
description: A good year for movies means a competitive awards season.
content: A great year for movies, as 2023 was, means a lot to look forward to as awards season begins. Things get started tonight with the Golden Globes ceremony, and later this week it’s on to nominations for the Screen Actors Guild and Producers Guild of America Awards. The big one — the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences — will announce its nominations for the 96th Oscars on Jan. 23.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: A Small-Town Stabbing Takes On a Larger Significance for France
description: The death might have been just a local tragedy. But some of the suspects were from an immigrant community, turning the case into a cause célèbre for the far right.
content: The traditional village ball 18 minutes outside the city ended in the traditional way: young men fighting outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Channeling the Pain of Chinese Immigrants, in Music and Verse
description: “Angel Island,” an oratorio by Huang Ruo, brings to life the stark poetry of the people who were detained on the California island in the early 1900s.
content: In “Angel Island,” a staged oratorio about the anguish and isolation of Chinese detainees at Angel Island Immigration Station in California, a choir recites a poem about tyranny and misfortune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: With Time Running Short, Liz Cheney Implores Republicans to Reject Trump
description: She endorsed efforts to remove him from the ballot and said, “Tell the world who we are with your vote. Tell them that we are a good and a great nation.”
content: In a flurry of appearances and commentary, former Representative Liz Cheney has stepped up her denunciations of former President Donald J. Trump in a last-ditch effort to persuade Republicans not to nominate him again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: In ‘Beautyland,’ an Awkward Alien Reports From Earth by Fax Machine
description: In Marie-Helene Bertino’s remarkable funny-sad novel, the young visitor and her mother find the means to persevere in the aisles of a cosmetics store.
content: “He was too good for this earth,” Abraham Lincoln said of a son who died young.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Prospect of a Rematch of Biden-Trump Causes Young Voters to Retreat
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 7, 2024.
content: “The biggest thing that my generation is begging for is for someone to be honest, and that is something we’re lacking from both sides.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Misguided War on the SAT
description: Colleges have fled standardized tests, on the theory that they hurt diversity. That’s not what the research shows.
content: After the Covid pandemic made it difficult for high school students to take the SAT and ACT, dozens of selective colleges dropped their requirement that applicants do so. Colleges described the move as temporary, but nearly all have since stuck to a test-optional policy. It reflects a backlash against standardized tests that began long before the pandemic, and many people have hailed the change as a victory for equity in higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Eddie Izzard Doesn’t Trust This Whole Falling in Love Business
description: “I don’t have a relationship, and I’m very happy and have got all this work to do,” says the comedian turned politician.
content: “I don’t have a relationship, and I’m very happy and have got all this work to do,” says the comedian turned politician.
source.name: The New York Times
